inlineContent.text: The YubiKit framework is distributed using the Swift Package Manager. To add the framework to your project follow these steps:
Select your project.
Choose the “Package Dependencies” tab.
Press the plus-button to bring up the add package dialog.
Enter
in the search field and select the Yubico Swift Package.
Press the “Add Package” button to add the SDK to your project.
If you want your app to communicate with YubiKeys via NFC you need to add the wireless entitlement, list of NFC
application identifiers and a NFC Privacy statement to the application.
Add Wireless entitlement
Select your project.
Select your application target.
Choose the “Signing & Capabilities” tab.
Click the “+”-button to add a new capability.
Select the “Near Field Communication Tag” capability.
Add list of NFC application identifiers
Choose the “Info” tab.
Add the “ISO7816 application identifiers for NFC” key to the “Custom iOS Target Properties”.
Add the Yubico NFC application identifiers to enable communication with the different
applications on the YubiKey.

code: A000000527200101  // YubiKey application/OTP (for HMAC SHA1 challenge-response)

inlineContent.text: Add a NFC Privacy description
Add the “Privacy - NFC Usage Scan Description” key and a string that describes what you will use NFC for in
the application e.g “The application needs access to NFC reading to communicate with your YubiKey.”
To support YubiKeys connected via the USB-C port on a device running iOS 16 or higher, you need to add the
entitlement to your application.
Select the application entitlements file.
Add the
entitlement to the entitlement list.
The SmartCard/USB-C connection only support the CCID based applications on the YubiKey and does not support U2F, FIDO2 or OTP.

Now that your project is configured, you can start connecting to YubiKeys. YubiKit provides different connection types depending on how the YubiKey is connected to the device.
YubiKit handles three different connection methods:
NFC
: Short-range wireless communication (iOS only)
USB-C
: Direct USB connection via SmartCard interface
Lightning
: YubiKey 5Ci connected to Lightning port (iOS only)
Each connection type works differently, so let’s explore how to use them.
NFC connections are user-initiated and short-lived. The user must bring their YubiKey close to their device:

code: // Use the connection quickly - NFC sessions have a timeout
let session = try await OATHSession.makeSession(connection: connection)
// Always close NFC connections with a user message
// Handle connection errors (user cancelled, no YubiKey found, etc.)

inlineContent.text: NFC connections automatically show the iOS NFC interface and require user interaction to complete.
Wired connections are persistent - they stay connected until the YubiKey is unplugged:

code: // Connect to any wired YubiKey (USB-C or Lightning)
let session = try await OATHSession.makeSession(connection: connection)
// Monitor for disconnection or close when done

inlineContent.text: The
method automatically detects whether you’re using USB-C or Lightning.
For more control, you can connect to specific interfaces:

code: alertMessage: "Hold your YubiKey near the phone"

inlineContent.text: Critical:
Connections must be explicitly closed. You can only have one active connection to a YubiKey at any time.
Exclusive access
: Only one connection can exist per YubiKey at any time
Manual closure required
: Dropping a connection reference does NOT automatically close it - you must call
Resource blocking
: An unclosed connection prevents new connections (throws
Connections are value types that act as exclusive access tokens to the underlying hardware resource.
Once you have a connection, create sessions to access different YubiKey applications:

code: let session = try await OATHSession.makeSession(connection: connection)
let session = try await PIVSession.makeSession(connection: connection)
let session = try await ManagementSession.makeSession(connection: connection)

inlineContent.text: In SwiftUI or UIKit apps, you typically want to maintain persistent connections and react to connection changes. See
for complete examples of reactive connection management patterns that automatically update your UI when YubiKeys are plugged in or removed.
CLI applications often use a simpler approach with a single connection per operation. See
for examples of how command-line tools handle connections for one-time operations.
Now you’re ready to build YubiKey applications! Check out the sample projects to see complete implementations:
OATHSample
: Shows how to build a TOTP authenticator app with SwiftUI
PIVTool
: Demonstrates PIV operations for certificates and digital signatures
You can also build the complete SDK documentation by selecting “Product” -> “Build Documentation” in Xcode. This gives you access to the full YubiKit API reference.
Select an iOS target when building documentation to include all connection types.
